Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: My phone buzzed urgently just as I was settling in to watch the live-streamed candidate forum for my district. I’d been looking forward to it all week—this was my chance to hear the candidates’ positions and maybe even submit a question. But the message on my screen made my heart race: it was my friend, stranded on the side of the highway, scared and alone, asking if I could come get them right away. As a friend, I knew I should drop everything and help, especially this late at night. But as a citizen, I felt a responsibility to stay informed and participate in the forum, especially with the election coming up and so many important issues at stake. I stared at my phone, torn between the immediate need of someone I cared about and my duty to my community, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
